body.p: To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette Governor of the State of Kentucky

Your petitioners the undersigned would respectfully represent that they are now and have been for some time doing business as Partners on market street two doors above 3d Street as Wholesal & Retail dealers in Watches and Jewelry &c: and that they have a repairing Shop in which the same is repaired; That at the present Term of the City Court of Louisville they were indicted jointly for setting up and managing a Lottery, under the Statute forbidding it: They plead not guilty to the Indictment, but they were fined the sum of One hundred dollars each, before the said Court: they state that they never did set up or manage a Lottery or any thing like it but having incurred the especial displeasure of two of the public officers they were presented by them on the above ^accusation^ their names are to the first of the accusation a copy of which is appended hereto: They state, that they never set up or managed a Lottery in the City of Louisville or elsewhere: Ben Ewing (a policement) being introduced as a Witness testified that the Defts in thier store Kept in a glass-case set upon their count a number of paper boxes, and that a purchaser paid one dollar for a paper-box, with the privilege of contents: that he bought a box and obtained in it a set of Jewelry worth more than a dollar, that he selected the box for a dollar, and the Merchant
delivered it to him having received the dollar he said he thought it was a sort of Lottery: Pat Dillon said He had information that the Defendants had set up a Lottery He knew nothing personally about it: He never had bought any thing from them: and this was all that the state proved.: Your petitioners then introduced Mr J W. Surrey who stated that he had bought a box for one dollar: and upon opening it, It contained a watch worth $25.00 $30.00 He stated that He Knew the Machining of a Lottery, and was well acquainted with Lottery-schemes, and that the business done by the Defts was not a Lottery He was often in thier place of business: and that they had not ^managed^ or set up any Lottery. Mr Richard stated that he was a watch repairer and that his shop was at the window in the house occupied by Defts; and was acquainted with their business, and that they were engaged as wholsal & Retail Watch & Jewelry; that He was there night and day, and that Defendants had never set a Lottery or managed a Lottery or dispersal of Money or prospects by way of Lottery:

Your Petitioners stated this all, in Consideration of the above they pray your Excellency to remit to them, the fine save fees & costs. they are poor having lost all by the troubles of the Country with large families, and to pay an unjust fine would be hard indeed
and further impoverish them; the are very respectfully you humble petitioners
E H Wilham & J E Russell
J E Russell states that the above is true in substance
Sworn to by J E. Russell beform me this 12th day of August 1865

Saml Matlock J. P. J. C
SM
Aug 19
1865
